prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for not turning down a girl at a wedding?
So over the weekend my ex got married and I was invited to the wedding. It was kinda weird but I am really close with the groom and frankly his whole family so it wasn't that surprising.

But a couple of days before the wedding the soon to be bride told me that I wasn't allowed to hit on any women at her wedding. Which I thought was really weird to make such a direct demand but whatever it was her wedding.

So at the wedding I am having a good time, I am drinking, mingling, and dancing and just having a good time. I am not out trying to pick up anyone but I am having a good time. As the reception is winding down one of the bridesmaids asked me what my plans were for the night and invites me to her hotel room and I agreed.

The bride is now pretty pissed at me. 1 I don't know why it bothers her so much, seems strange and 2 I didn't break my promise, she picked me up not the other way around.

So am I an asshole for not rejecting a girl at my ex's wedding?
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

The author might have thought he was following the rule, but the bride's perspective is that he was still engaging in behavior she didn't want. 

Also, the bride's reaction might be about the perception. Even if he didn't initiate, the fact that he went to the hotel room with someone could be seen as inappropriate, regardless of who approached whom. The author's responsibility is to respect the bride's boundaries, even if the other person initiated. So maybe he's in the wrong for not turning down the invitation, because he could have respected the bride's wishes more by not engaging in any behavior that could be seen as hitting on someone, regardless of who extended the invitation. 

But then again, if the bride's instruction was to not approach others, and he was approached, perhaps he's not at fault. However, the scenario is a bit ambiguous.
